官方媒体称，约旦周三将在安曼与美国总统乔·拜登以及埃及和巴勒斯坦领导人举行四方峰会，讨论加沙战争对该地区的“危险”影响。

一份官方声明称，讨论将集中于如何停止“加沙正在进行的战争，以及如何找到能够恢复和平进程的政治视野”。

约旦国王阿卜杜拉还将分别与埃及总统阿卜杜勒·法塔赫·塞西和巴勒斯坦总统马哈茂德·阿巴斯举行三方峰会。

国王周二警告不要试图将巴勒斯坦难民推入埃及或约旦，并补充说人道主义局势必须在加沙和约旦河西岸内部得到​​解决。在 1967 年中东战争期间，安曼将包括东耶路撒冷在内的约旦河西岸输给了以色列，该国担心不断扩大的暴力可能会产生影响，因为约旦人口中很大一部分是巴勒斯坦人。

6月23日，一艘漂流在地中海的橡皮船上的一名乘客拨打救援热线请​​求帮助。这艘载有 14 名来自中东和非洲移民的船在波涛汹涌的水域中耗尽了燃料。一名男乘客刚刚溺水身亡。

根据热线运营商 Alarm Phone 记录的位置数据，这艘船距离马耳他海岸约 70 海里，位于这个小岛国的搜救区内。在这些区域内，各国有义务根据国际法协调搜救行动。

尽管如此，根据对参与救援的人道主义组织的采访以及路透社对这些组织记录事件的笔记、电子邮件和录音的审查，马耳他当局拒绝了这一求救电话以及至少 32 起有关该情况的其他通讯。

有一次，马耳他救援协调中心的一名接听电话的人拒绝了一名人道主义工作人员打来的有关该船的电话。根据德国非营利搜救组织 Sea-Watch 向路透社提供的通话录音，接线员说：“你让我的线路一直占线。”该组织是接到通知的几家组织之一。有关这艘遇险船只的当局。

幸存者告诉医疗援助组织无国界医生组织（MSF）的采访者，一艘马耳他军舰最终到达了失事船只，但拒绝了乘客直接的救援请求。路透社对无国界医生行动照片和视频的评论显示，无国界医生的一艘名为“Geo Barents”的船只后来救出了乘客，并将他们带到了意大利。

据在该地区开展活动的人道主义组织和非政府组织称，这一事件是马耳他拒绝救援载有前往欧洲的移民的船只的最新例子。国际法专家表示，此案尤其令人不安，因为马耳他武装部队据称拒绝援助乘客。

人道主义组织无国界医生组织、Sea-Watch 和 Alarm Phone 向路透社描述了该事件的细节，但此前尚未报道过。

南安普顿大学海事法讲师阿伊霍亚·坎帕斯·贝拉斯科 (Ainhoa Campàs Velasco) 表示，马耳他没有及时回应求救信号并协调救援，没有履行国际法规定的义务。 “船的类型、海况、它们都过于拥挤——这是明显的遇险情况。”

马耳他当局，包括总理办公室的发言人，拒绝回答有关该事件的问题。负责协调搜​​救工作的马耳他武装部队发言人表示，马耳他搜救区有关“非正规移民”的所有报告都“立即跟进”。

发言人萨布丽娜·博格（Sabrina Borg）在给路透社的电子邮件中写道：“搜救行动是根据适用的国际公约、法规并通过主管当局进行协调的。” “与所有情况一样，主管当局履行注意义务。”

一位意大利政客四月份指责马耳他未能救助该国搜救区内的遇险船只。执政的意大利兄弟党成员托马索·福蒂在意大利广播节目中表示，马耳他当局“一直假装没有看到，也从不干预”，这给意大利海岸警卫队带来了更大的压力。福蒂没有回应置评请求。

参与地中海救援的人道主义组织也回应了这一批评。 “根据我们的经验，马耳他不太可能救援，”Sea-Watch 发言人 Oliver Kulikowski 说，该组织在 6 月份帮助最终救援了这艘船。 “马耳他正在尽一切努力避免承担责任并让人们抵达马耳他。”

内政部发言人表示，马耳他希望建立一个公平、安全的移民和庇护制度，让“真正需要国际保护的人得到迅速承认”，而那些没有合法权利留在马耳他的人则被送回原籍国。马耳他发言人尼尔·阿佐帕尔迪·费里吉 (Neil Azzopardi Ferriggi) 表示，马耳他将继续努力减少导致数千人海上死亡的非法过境。

他说：“成千上万的人继续冒着生命危险试图到达欧盟，而走私者却继续从移民的希望和痛苦中获利，这是不可接受的。”

“尖叫求救”

在第一次求救信号发出三十九小时后，无国界医生救出了留在船上的三名青少年，其中包括两名妇女和八名男子。该援助小组收集了三名幸存者的证词，并与路透社分享。该通讯社无法独立采访幸存者或确认他们的叙述的全部细节。他们的下落不明。

两名幸存者告诉无国界医生，这艘橡皮艇于 6 月 21 日凌晨 3 点左右离开利比亚苏尔特。机上有14名来自叙利亚和南苏丹的人，其中包括两名妇女和三名14至17岁的青少年。

6 月 22 日下午 4 点 28 分，在海上航行了一天半后，船上有人向 Alarm Phone 拨打了求救电话，该网络将地中海的求救电话转发给紧急服务部门。根据提供给路透社的电子邮件副本，报警电话通过电子邮件向马耳他和意大利当局通报了该船的位置，并指出该船已耗尽燃料。

电子邮件称：“船上的人正在紧急寻求帮助。”

根据警报电话记录，在接下来的几个小时内，警报电话通过电子邮件向马耳他和意大利当局通报了该船的最新情况，并至少四次致电马耳他搜救协调中心。所有联系人均未得到回应。

到第二天早上，即 6 月 23 日，幸存者告诉无国界医生组织，他们已经没有食物和水了。他们将空的燃料容器绑在船的两侧，用作漂浮装置，以防翻船。

中午12点30分左右，其中一个空燃料容器落入水中，一名23岁的叙利亚男子跳入水中将其捞起。一名27岁目击事件的男子告诉无国界医生，水罐距离船仅一米，但海浪很大，而且他没有穿救生衣。乘客们告诉无国界医生，他们试图将船移近这名叙利亚男子，但没有成功，因为他努力保持在水面上。

中午12时46分，报警电话致电马耳他搜救协调中心，报告有人落水。位置数据显示，这艘船位于马耳他东南部 74 海里处，位于该国的搜救区内。

根据报警电话的通话记录，在搜救协调中心接听电话的人立即挂断了电话。

幸存者告诉无国界医生，这名叙利亚男子最终消失在海浪之下。

一小时后，Sea-Watch 运营的一架飞机发现了这艘漂流船。根据海洋观察发给马耳他当局的电子邮件副本，只有少数人穿着救生衣。根据 Sea-Watch 工作人员记录并经路透社分析的位置数据和视频，最近的船只是一艘马耳他巡逻艇，距离 15 海里，正驶向马耳他。

海洋观察工作人员表示，海洋观察向马耳他武装部队 P51 号巡逻船发送了 3 次无线电信号，但没有得到回应。马耳他武装部队负责管理该国的搜救协调中心，负责协调和指导马耳他境内的救援工作。

海洋观察组织还发出了五一节呼吁，召唤附近的船只来帮助漂流的船只。海洋观察工作人员表示，马耳他当局或巡逻艇均未做出回应。

“这就像拨打 911，但紧急热线没有回应，”海洋观察发言人库利科斯基说。

根据船舶追踪数据，一艘挂着加蓬旗的油轮“拉科尼亚”号确实响应了五一劳动节的号召，并改变了航线，在该船旁边停泊了两个多小时。根据油轮船长和海洋观察工作人员之间的对话录音，油轮于晚上 9 点 20 分左右出发，一艘快艇的船员自称是马耳他武装部队，要求船长将船只的监控交给他们。该油轮的船长和船东没有回应置评请求。马耳他武装部队拒绝就油轮的参与发表评论。

入境人数急剧下降

目前还没有地中海遇险呼叫和海上救援的官方统计数据。但近年来，随着欧洲其他地区的移民数量激增，马耳他通过海路抵达的移民数量急剧下降。

联合国难民事务高级专员的数据显示，2022 年有超过 152,000 人经地中海抵达欧洲，较 2019 年增加了 49%。这些年来，意大利的海上入境人数增加了 814%，从 11,500 人增至 105,131 人。马耳他的入境人数下降了 87%，从 3,406 人减少到 444 人。

国际特赦组织 2020 年的一份报告指责马耳他拖延或拒绝救援。报告称，其中一些事件涉及的船只在被“推回”利比亚之前已经到达马耳他搜救区。该报告引用了移民证词、非政府组织、政府消息来源和媒体报道。

马耳他否认参与抵制活动，欧洲人权法院宣布这种活动违反国际法。

马耳他领导人表示，这个人口仅超过 50 万的小国无法像意大利这样的富裕国家那样轻松应对大量移民的涌入，意大利的人口是马耳他的 100 多倍。内政部长拜伦·卡米莱里 (Byron Camilleri) 在 10 月 7 日与其他欧盟官员举行的会议上对无证移民采取了强硬立场。卡米莱里表示，抵达马耳他的移民中有 70% 已被遣返，重要的是“发出明确的信息，他们没有权利留下来”。

批评人士称，这一立场推动了马耳他的搜救行动。英国国际与比较法研究所研究移民法的马耳他学者让-皮埃尔·高奇表示：“他们感兴趣的是关闭边境，阻止人们抵达，而不是履行搜救义务。”

救援人员介入

幸存者告诉无国界医生，一艘马耳他巡逻艇于 6 月 23 日日落后抵达漂流船，此时距离这名年轻人溺水已有十多个小时。三名身穿白色防护服的男子给了乘客能量饼干、手电筒和三加仑燃料，并敦促他们继续前往意大利。位置数据显示，该船当时距离意大利超过 78 海里。

幸存者告诉无国界医生，乘客告诉这些人他们很害怕，不想留在船上。

几个小时后，橡皮艇再次耗尽燃料。幸存者告诉无国界医生，马耳他巡逻艇返航后又给乘客提供了三个集装箱燃料。

一艘无国界医生船只于6月23日深夜抵达该地区，船员通知马耳他当局他们可以营救乘客。等了几个小时后，没有得到回应，无国界医生接起了13名幸存者，并将他们带到意大利拉斯佩齐亚。无国界医生组织的工作人员不知道乘客之后发生了什么，因为该组织在移民离开救援船后并没有追踪他们。

无国界医生组织向路透社提供了一名幸存者在途中创作的一幅图画的副本。它描绘了一名落水男子高高举起双臂的情景。在底角，艺术家用阿拉伯语写道：“愿上帝安息他的灵魂。”

阿塞拜疆周二表示，下周将与其亲密盟友土耳其举行军事演习。

这个以突厥族为主的南高加索国家国防部在其网站上表示，纪念土耳其共和国成立一百周年的演习将于10月23日至25日在多个地区举行。

其中包括首都巴库、纳希切万地区以及自 2020 年以来从亚美尼亚族控制下夺取的阿塞拜疆领土，土耳其对此表示欢迎。

纳希切万与土耳其和伊朗接壤，但在地理上与阿塞拜疆大陆隔着亚美尼亚。

上个月，阿塞拜疆总统伊利哈姆· 阿利耶夫在纳希切万与土耳其总统塔伊普·埃尔多安举行会谈，不到一周后，阿塞拜疆军队席卷了亚美尼亚族控制的纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫地区，这是阿塞拜疆最后一个不受巴库控制的地区。

在会议上，阿利耶夫得到了埃尔多安对在阿塞拜疆西部和纳希切万之间途经亚美尼亚建立陆地走廊的支持，但埃尔多安反对这一想法。

苏格兰领导人胡姆扎·优素福相信，他的独立梦想将在未来十年实现，尽管他的执政党因现代历史上最严重的危机而失去了支持。

支持独立的苏格兰民族党是苏格兰近二十年的主导政党，但由于内讧、选民疲劳和丑闻（包括其魅力十足的前领导人尼古拉·斯特金被捕）而受到损害。

英国主要反对党工党本月在苏格兰赢回了一个议会席位，在一次投票中驱逐了苏格兰民族党，这表明该党的数十名政客可能会在下次选举中失去席位，而上周另一名苏格兰民族党议员因欺凌指控而叛逃到保守党。

“这很困难，假装没有任何意义。这可能是我们党在现代历史上面临的最困难的六个月，”优素福在阿伯丁举行的政党年度会议上告诉路透社。

“不幸的是，这些事情向你袭来，不是一两个，而是给你带来了许多挑战。但尽管面临这些挑战，如果你看看几乎每一次的民意调查，你会发现我们继续领先反对派。”

在 2019 年的上一次选举中，苏格兰民族党获得了 59 个席位中的 48 个，成为西欧最具统治力的政党之一。但 YouGov 上周的一项民意调查显示，苏格兰工党的支持率仅为两个百分点。工党曾经是苏格兰的主导党，在 2019 年赢得了一个席位。

“坚如磐石”的独立支持

优素福表示，他对独立的苏格兰即将到来充满信心。尽管苏格兰民族党的支持率下降，但民意调查显示苏格兰在独立问题上仍存在大致分歧。

“对独立的支持坚如磐石，但对苏格兰民族党的支持有所下降，”他说。当被问及苏格兰是否会在未来十年内获得独立时，他说：“毫无疑问。我希望这会在十年内实现。”

2014 年，苏格兰人以 55% 比 45% 的投票结果拒绝结束与英格兰长达 300 多年的联盟。但民族主义者认为，2016 年脱欧公投改变了一切，因为大多数苏格兰选民都反对。

在前首相鲍里斯·约翰逊的领导下，支持独立的情绪更加强烈，他在苏格兰极不受欢迎。

优素福表示，他需要提出一个关于独立的苏格兰的积极愿景，包括更好地保护工人和努力解决贫困问题，因为批评伦敦首相里希·苏纳克政府只能到此为止。

他认为，对独立的持续支持也将有助于克服未来最大的战役——说服威斯敏斯特政府同意举行第二次公投。

英国最高法院去年表示，未经英国议会批准，苏格兰政府不得举行第二次独立公投。

Days before candidates officially register for Indonesia's elections, a game-changing ruling by the nation's constitutional court has sparked concern over the integrity of the vote in the world's third-largest democracy.

On Monday, the court removed the 40 years minimum age requirement for presidential or vice-presidential candidates if they had previously been elected to regional posts, potentially opening the way for President Joko Widodo's 36-year-old son to contest.

The ruling, issued by a court headed by the president's brother-in-law, has raised fears of a resurgence of patronage politics in a country that only 25 years ago emerged from the authoritarian rule of strongman leader Suharto.

"I don't think there is a single person in Indonesia who wasn't aware the application was fundamentally about whether the president's son could run as a vice presidential candidate," said Tim Lindsey, an expert in Indonesian law at the University of Melbourne.

The court and the presidential palace did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The Southeast Asian nation will hold simultaneous presidential and legislative election on Feb. 14 next year. Jokowi, as the president is known, is ineligible to run after serving the maximum two terms.

But Monday's ruling paves the way for his eldest son and mayor of Surakarta city, Gibran Rakabuming Raka.

The decision comes amid rampant speculation the president - once lauded for breaking the mould of the Suharto-era old guard - is lining up his son to become the vice-presidential running mate of Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto, who is now leading in the polls.

Gibran is one of the strongest potential running mates for Prabowo, an official at the former general's Gerindra party said on Tuesday.

Analysts say Jokowi's support will provide a significant boost for Prabowo, Suharto's former son-in-law and also the son of a former cabinet minister.

The Indonesian leader was earlier seen likely to be hedging his bets between the top two contenders for president, but the analysts said the court decision implies he will back Prabowo.

Prabowo, 72, lost to Jokowi in the previous two presidential elections.

"It's a scandalous decision because many Indonesians see it as the court losing independence, and a conflict of interest and intimidation leading it to allow the current president, who can't sit for a third term, make up for that by building a dynasty," said Lindsey.

The decision, said Bivitri Susanti of Indonesia's Jentera School of Law, was "worse than Suharto".

SITTING 'DODO'

As the popular leader of the Southeast Asia's largest economy, analysts say Jokowi has been manoeuvring behind the scenes to safeguard his legacy and extend his influence beyond his term in office.

An adept political operator, Jokowi may be betting that his high approval ratings will help him weather any backlash, but Goenawan Mohamad, founder of investigative magazine Tempo, said that was a gamble set to fail.

"In 2024, Jokowi will not be at the centre of power. He will not be a lame-duck power, he will be a dodo. It is hubris to think that his popularity will stay intact, or his son will survive the political revenge," he said.

What is remarkable, analysts say, is that Jokowi has managed to stay so popular despite critics pointing to a trend of democratic regression, including the weakening of state institutions.

Judge Saldi Isra, one of four dissenting judges in the nine-judge bench that issued Monday's rulings, said he was perturbed by the seemingly contradictory stands taken by his colleagues, who previously rejected similar petitions.

"This is the first time that I came across an extraordinarily strange event, which can be described as beyond the limits of fair reasoning," he said.

Elections in Indonesia are often colourful and boisterous, and invariably followed by election disputes, applications for which are filed at the constitutional court.

"The court decision has destroyed the people's trust in an independent judiciary and any future political dispute will easily tear the country apart," said Tempo's Goenawan.

The Jakarta Post, Indonesia's leading English-language daily, said in an editorial: "We must raise a red flag over the probity of the upcoming election. The game appears rigged to give certain players the upper hand."

Argentine teenager Tomas Kremenchuzky is getting ready to vote in his first ever presidential election on Oct. 22, the most open and uncertain race in his lifetime, where the frontrunner candidate is threatening to upend the country's economic model.

Argentina is one of a handful of Latin American countries that allows 16 and 17-year-olds the right to vote. Kremenchuzky, nicknamed "Toto," 17, is part of that teenage electorate.

Many young Argentines are struggling to find opportunities in a country where a cost-of-living crisis and triple-digit inflation has compounded investor wariness after years of political and economic volatility.

That has been a big factor in the popularity of the presidential frontrunner - wild-haired and brash political outsider, Javier Milei , who wears leather jackets, sings rock songs to his fans, berates "thieving" politicians and wants to "burn down" the central bank.

"Because of the way Milei speaks, I buy everything he says. He's got a way of expressing himself that reaches people," said Toto, who comes from a well-off family, plays soccer and goes to a private school in Buenos Aires.

In an August open primary vote, Toto voted for conservative Patricia Bullrich - which he puts down to influence from his parents - but says he could shift his vote in October to Milei if the libertarian convinces him in election debates.

"Milei proposes something different, which later in practice may turn out to very good - or very bad," Toto said.

However, Milei's conservative social views and promise of sharp cuts to government spending are off-putting to some young voters.

Rocio Pozzetti, 16, who attends a public art school, fears Milei will undo social safety nets, hitting the poor the hardest. She is voting for Peronist ruling party candidate Sergio Massa, despite the economic turbulence he has overseen as economy minister.

"Massa is the only candidate who represents my ideals and can build a better country, with social justice," Pozzetti said. "It is worrying that people support Milei."

EVERYONE IS ANGRY WITH POLITICIANS

Pozzetti, who studies theater and dance, said she understands the anger pushing people to ditch the familiar in favor of the unknown.

"I think many voted for Milei because he was a new face and he represents all that anger that everyone has with politics and so they could identify with him," said Pozzetti.

Noelle Chab, an 18-year-old Buenos Aires resident, voted for Milei in the primaries and will do so again in October because she believes he represents change and she wants to "remove" the Peronist government.

"Javier Milei is the only one who represents a change in Argentine politics," said Chab. "It is evident that this is the worst government in Argentine history, it did a lot of harm and continues to do harm."

Simon Rubinstein, 17, a fan of soccer, Formula 1 and "Star Wars," likes Milei's ideas about shrinking the state, but is afraid of some of his proposals, including dollarization and laxer controls on guns.

"Because of the country's economic situation, regardless of who wins, there are going to be at least a few bad years," said Rubinstein, who voted for Bullrich in the primary.

The young voters all said they worry about Milei's socially conservative views, including his strong anti-abortion stance. Abortion was legalized in Argentina in late 2020 and would be difficult to overturn.

"It seems to me it will be impossible for people to endorse him on this issue and that the abortion law will continue to be as it is now," Toto said.

"No one can confront Muslims and the resistance forces if the Zionist regime's crimes against Palestinians continue ... the bombardment of Gaza must stop immediately," Khamenei said.

"The Zionist regime's officials should be tried for their crimes against Palestinians in Gaza," he added.

Israel has vowed to annihilate Hamas after the group's gunmen killed 1,300 people, mainly civilians, during a rampage through southern Israeli towns on Oct. 7, the deadliest single day in Israel's 75-year history.

It has imposed a total blockade on the enclave, blocking food, fuel and medical supplies, which are rapidly running out.

Belgium was searching on Tuesday for a gunman who killed two Swedish citizens and wounded a third person on Monday in Brussels in what Prime Minister Alexander De Croo called a brutal terrorist attack.

The country has raised the security alert status of its capital city to the highest level, with increased police presence, particularly for Swedish people and institutions, and warned the public to be extra vigilant and avoid unnecessary travel.

"Last night three people left for what was supposed to be a wonderful soccer party. Two of them lost their lives in a brutal terrorist attack," De Croo told a news conference.

"The perpetrator targeted specifically Swedish supporters who were in Brussels to attend a Red Devils soccer match. Two Swedish compatriots passed away. A third person is recovering from severe injures," de Croo said.

Belgium was hosting Sweden in a Euro 2024 qualifying match on Monday evening. The match was abandoned at halftime.

A man, who identified himself as a member of the Islamic State, claimed responsibility in a video posted online.

Belgian Justice Minister Vincent Van Quickenborne told the news conference the suspect was a 45-year-old Tunisian man who sought asylum in Belgium in November 2019 and was known to police over people smuggling and illegal residence in Belgium.

Police are still searching for him.

Belgium has increased the presence of police in Brussels, especially around places linked to the Swedish community. Authorities say the perpetrator chose his victims because of their nationality.

A Belgian federal prosecutor said there was no evidence that the attacker had any link to the recent renewed conflict between Israel and Palestinian militants.

Sweden in August raised its terror alert to the second-highest level, warning of an increase in threats against Swedish interests abroad, after Koran burnings and other acts in Sweden against Islam's holiest text outraged Muslims and triggered threats from jihadists.

The suspected assailant, calling himself Abdesalem Al Guilani, claimed in a video on social media that he was a fighter for Allah.

The shooting comes at a time of heightened security concerns in some European countries linked to the Israel-Hamas conflict . France is deploying 7,000 extra troops onto its streets after a teacher was fatally stabbed on Friday in an attack President Emmanuel Macron condemned as "barbaric Islamic terrorism."

Video footage of the Brussels attack posted on the Het Laatste Nieuws newspaper website showed a man in an orange jacket on a scooter at a street intersection with a rifle first firing five shots, then following people fleeing into a building before firing again.

According to a media transcript of the video message recorded by the self-declared perpetrator, he said he had killed Swedes to take revenge in the name of Muslims.

  • Iranian foreign minister promises preemptive actions
  • Hamas says it seeks freedom for prisoners held by Israel
  • Russia's Putin speaks to Israel's Netanyahu by phone

Diplomats renewed calls for aid to the besieged Gaza Strip while Iran's foreign minister said Israel would not be allowed to act there without facing consequences, warning of "preemptive action" in the coming hours.

US President Joe Biden weighed a visit to Israel laden with political and security risks, underscored on Monday when US Secretary of State Antony Blinken was forced to shelter in a bunker for five minutes while meeting Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu when sirens went off in Tel Aviv.

Israel has vowed to annihilate the Hamas movement that rules Gaza, after fighters of the armed wing of the Iran-backed Palestinian Hamas movement burst across the barrier to Israel on Oct. 7, gunning down 1,300 Israelis, mainly civilians, in the deadliest day in Israel's 75-year-old history.

Israel has since put Gaza, home to 2.3 million Palestinians, under a total blockade and pounded it with unprecedented air strikes, and is widely expected to launch a ground assault.

Gaza authorities say more than 2,800 people have been killed there, around a quarter of them children, and more than 10,000 wounded are in hospitals desperately short of supplies.

Hamas said on Monday it had fired a "barrage of missiles," toward Jerusalem and Tel Aviv.

Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian told state TV: "Leaders of the Resistance will not allow the Zionist regime to take any action in Gaza. ... All options are open and we cannot be indifferent to the war crimes committed against the people of Gaza."

"The resistance front is capable of waging a long-term war with the enemy (Israel)... in the coming hours, we can expect a preemptive action by the resistance front," he said, without elaborating.

Iran, which backs Hamas, refers to regional countries and forces opposed to Israel and the United States as a "resistance front." Amirabdollahian said it was not limited to Hezbollah in Lebanon and added: "This front was formed throughout the region to preserve the independence of nations and counter repeated aggressions by the Zionist regime over the past years."

Last week, Iran's top authority Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said Tehran was not involved in the Hamas attack on Israel, but hailed what he called Israel's "irreparable" military and intelligence defeat.

Earlier on Monday, Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi said that while Tehran supported the Palestinian cause, the resistance front against Israel made its own independent decisions.

Diplomatic efforts have concentrated on getting aid into Gaza through the Rafah crossing with Egypt , the sole route out that is not controlled by Israel. Cairo said the Rafah crossing was not officially closed but was inoperable due to Israeli strikes on the Gaza side.

Netanyahu invited Biden to Israel. Biden has been outspoken in his support for Israel, Washington's closest Middle East ally. The White House declined to comment on any planning for the trip. National Security Council spokesperson Adrienne Watson said in a statement that "we have no new travel to announce."

Such a trip would be a rare and risky choice, showing American backing for Netanyahu as the US tries to avert a broader regional war involving Iran, its Lebanese ally Hezbollah, and Syria, and as food and fuel run low in Gaza .

It could, however, grant Biden fresh leverage to influence events on the ground and bolster his image at home.

Biden and Netanyahu, uncomfortable allies in the best of times, have joined forces despite being at odds over the path forward in the Middle East with Biden frequently stressing support for independent Israeli and Palestinian states.

A meeting in person would allow Biden to privately discuss concerns and possible red lines in a looming Israeli ground invasion.

A top Hamas leader said on Monday the group "has what it needs" to free all Palestinians in Israel's jails, indicating the militant group may try to use the Israelis it kidnapped as bargaining chips to secure the release of Palestinian prisoners.

Soon after Hamas official Khaled Meshaal made the remarks on the captives, who include Israelis and non-Israelis kidnapped by Hamas on Oct. 7, the group's armed wing separately said the non-Israelis were "guests" who would be released "when circumstances allow."

In the biggest sign yet that the war could spread to a new front, Israel ordered the evacuation on Monday of 28 villages in a two km- (1.2 mile-)deep zone near the Lebanese border.

Israel has said more than a million people in the northern half of Gaza must head to the southern half for their safety, even though Hamas has told them to stay put. While tens of thousands have fled south, the United Nations says there is no way to move so many people without causing a humanitarian catastrophe.

According to the United Nations, a million Gazans have already been driven from their homes. Power is out, sanitary water is scarce, and the last fuel for hospital emergency generators could be used up within a day.

Netanyahu said Israelis should prepare for a long battle.

"Now we are focused on one target: to unite forces and charge forward to victory. This requires determination because victory will take time," he told the Israeli parliament.

"And I have a message for Iran and Hezbollah, don't test us in the north. Don't make the same mistake you once made. Because today the price you will pay will be much heavier."

Russian President Vladimir Putin told Netanyahu on Monday that Moscow wanted to help prevent a humanitarian disaster in Gaza. The Kremlin readout of the call did not include any mention of the ceasefire Russia was trying to achieve by putting forward a resolution in the United Nations Security Council .

But Putin briefed Netanyahu on conversations with the leaders of Iran, Egypt, Syria and the Palestinian Authority in which the Kremlin said earlier that this had been discussed.

"A unanimous opinion was expressed on the need for an early ceasefire and the establishment of a humanitarian truce in order to urgently provide assistance to all those in need," it said of those conversations.

With each day of air strikes, Gazans have been clawing at the rubble of flattened buildings with bare hands to rescue neighbours and recover the dead, with virtually no mechanical equipment to clear away the wreckage.

Those trying to reach the southern border crossing inside Gaza described the route as perilous and under Israeli attack.

"On our way to the crossing they shelled Rafah Street and we started screaming," said one resident near the crossing, Hadeel Abu Dahoud. "Nowhere is safe in Gaza. Wherever we go there's shelling, shelling, crying, screaming, blood."
